description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Cooperation among different jurisdictional entities (e.g. treaties or agreements among countries or provinces)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: May 18, 2020, The Lithuanian Cabinet of Ministers agreed to reopen kindergartens and preschool groups. So will the non-formal education of children. Pre-school, pre-primary and non-formal education of children shall be carried out by ensuring the required conditions laid down by the State Commander of National Emergency Operations for public health safety, hygiene, and the provision of persons with necessary personal protective equipment. UPDATE: This overarching policy ends on 17 May 2020, as the restrictions are lifted for the youngest age groups while kept for the older children and adults.

description:
Starting from August 7, 2020, until November 8, 2020 the Government of Lithuania announced that non-formal education for children and adults will be carried out remotely or discontinued. The necessary conditions for public health safety, hygiene, provision of persons with necessary personal protective equipment must be ensured: 
disinfection; hand hygiene (washing and/or disinfection); prohibition to work for employees with symptoms or if isolation is prescribed.

This will not exempt other students and they will be required to continue wearing protective equipment covering nose and mouth.

description: Starting from June 17, 2021, until June 30, 2021, the Lithuanian government announced that in municipalities where a 14-day notification rate of COVID-19 (coronavirus infection) per 100 000 population is up to 200 cases - 5-11 grades will be allowed to return to contact education without testing. The municipalities are as follows: Birštonas, Biržai district, Elektrėnai, Ignalina district, Jurbarkas district, Joniškis district, Klaipėda district, Kretinga district, Kupiškis district, Mažeikiai district, Neringa, Pakruojis district, Pasvalys district, Rokiškis district, Skuodas district, Šiauliai district, Šilalė district, Telšiai district.

This restriction is till May 31, 2021. UPDATE: June 17, 2021, The Lithuanian government announced that 10 m2. per person will be ensured during matura examinations or their parts when attended by more than 10 pupils at a time till June 30, 2021.

description: May 10, 2021, The Lithuanian government announced that non-formal education for children will be provided remotely or suspended except foreign language proficiency assessment examinations (credits) attended by maximum 5 pupils, non-formal outdoor education activities for children attended by maximum 10 children and indoor non-formal education activities for children in the territories of some municipalities attended by maximum 5 children, while ensuring 20 m2 of service delivery space per child or only one child is present at a time until May 31, 2021. UPDATE: June 17, 2021, The Lithuanian government announced that non-formal education for children is held under the conditions laid down by the State Commander of National Emergency Operations for the management of the flow of people, safe physical distance, and other key requirements for public health safety, hygiene, and the provision of persons with necessary personal protective equipment. It is allowed to attend indoor activities at the same time and children camps for up to 30 children per group until June 30, 2021.

description: On 14th May 2021, Lithuania announced it will donate 200,000 COVID-19 vaccine shots of AstraZeneca to its eastern European neighbours including 100,000 to Ukraine. The shots will go to so-called EU Eastern Partnership countries, including 15,000 to Georgia and 11,000 to Moldova, the government said.Distribution of the remaining 74,000 doses will be decided later. The Eastern Partnership also includes Belarus, Azerbaijan and Armenia.The vaccines will be distributed by Oct. 1, mostly between July and September, when Lithuania expects to have a surplus.

description:
On 6th August 2021, the Lithuanian Health Ministry announced that people in Lithuania who have been given the first shot of a Covid-19 vaccine may choose a different vaccine for their second dose. The people may currently mix BioNTech-Pfizer's Comirnaty vaccine with AstraZeneca's Vaxzevria. People are also recommended to choose a different vaccine for their second shot if they experience severe side effects after the first dose of Comirnaty or Vaxzevria. An interval of 56 to 84 days is recommended between the two different shots.

Upd: This is a one-time measure.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description:
Starting from May 18 2020, the Lithuanian government announced that the entry of persons and/or their private passenger cars into the territory of the Republic of Lithuania shall be allowed only at the following international state border crossing points: Kalvarija - Budzisko, Saločiai - Grenstale, Butingė - Rucava, Smėlynė - Medume and Lazdijai - Ogrodniki. The entry of diplomatic transport shall be allowed at all the road state border crossing points. In exceptional cases, the entry of persons and/or their private passenger cars shall be allowed into the territory of the Republic of Lithuania at other international border crossing points specified in this
subparagraph, where there is a permission by the Head of the State Border Guard Service under the Ministry of the Interior of the Republic of Lithuania or his authorised person.

description: On 7 April 2020, the Parliament of Lithuania approved a pay rise of 60–100 percent for healthcare workers, including medical residents, working in coronavirus hotspots during the lockdown. Respective amendments to the Law on Prevention and Control of Communicable Diseases in Humans were passed unanimously with 120 votes in favor. The salaries of medical workers working in the hotspots of highly dangerous communicable diseases would increase by 60 to 100 percent. The pay rise would be financed from the national budget, instead of the Compulsory Health Insurance Fund.

type_sub_cat: Doctors

description: Announced 8 April 2020 and starting 10 April, it will be mandatory to wear facemasks in public in Lithuania. Up until now, it has been only recommended to do so. Executives of legal entities or other responsible persons will face fines ranging from 1,500 to 6,000 euros.

description: Announced 8 April 2020 and starting 10 April, it will be mandatory to wear facemasks in public in Lithuania. Up until now, it has been only recommended to do so. The Seimas of Lithuania earlier increased fines for people flouting quarantine requirements and they now face fines ranging from 500 to 1,000 euros. Executives of legal entities or other responsible persons will face fines ranging from 1,500 to 6,000 euros. UPDATE: In the light of the epidemiological situation and the declining workload in the health sector, the requirements for wearing masks and self-isolation will change from Monday, 4 April. A decision of the State Commander of National Emergency Operations will waive the mandatory requirement to wear masks indoors, with the exception of health, care and nursing facilities and public transport.

description:
On April 29th, 2020, the Lithuanian Government has taken a decision to further ease the lockdown restrictions following the recommendations of the Ministry of Health. This will allow healthcare providers to resume services. 
The Government has decided to enable healthcare providers to resume their services once they are ready. They will have to ensure the availability of appropriate infection control measures to provide for the protection of their staff and patients. Healthcare providers are required to produce a plan for a phased resumption and provision of inpatient and outpatient healthcare services.

description: Starting from June 2 2020, the Lithuanian Ministry of Health announced that patients who are provided with so-called day inpatient services, that is, when a person comes to a medical institution in the morning, where procedures are performed, scheduled assistance is provided, and returns home in the evening, the test for the detection of coronavirus infection (COVID-19) will have to be carried out only in the case if a person experiences symptoms characteristic of this disease. This means that those who do not have any complaints, for example - do not feel a sore throat, difficulty breathing, do not have fever - do not have to perform such an examination for day inpatient services.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Fixed Health Testing stations (excluding drive-ins)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On June 3 2020, the LIthuanian Ministry of Health announced that rapid serological tests has been adopted. Serological tests will be used for several purposes: a) to check if a person has had COVID-19 b) as a late diagnosis, at least 14 days after the onset of coronavirus-specific symptoms, c) to assess what proportion of the population has become ill. It is envisaged that rapid tests could also be performed in cases where a person experiences clear clinical signs of coronavirus infection, but repeat PCR tests are negative.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
type_sub_cat: Other Health Testing
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On 14th March 2020, the Lithuanian government announced restrictions to be imposed on the flows of passengers using long-distance and
suburban regular passenger transport services: they shall be required to travel seated maintaining the distance of at least one meter from each other. Special safety precautions shall be taken by disinfecting the vehicles at the beginning and end of the trip for each route. This provision is recommended for urban passenger transport too.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Other Internal Border Restriction
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On 14th March 2020, the Lithuanian government announced restrictions to be imposed on the flows of passengers using long-distance and
suburban regular passenger transport services: they shall be required to travel seated maintaining the distance of at least one meter from each other. Special safety precautions shall be taken by disinfecting the vehicles at the beginning and end of the trip for each route. This provision is recommended for urban passenger transport too. UPDATE: Following the decision of the Government of the Republic of Lithuania to lift COVID-19 related national emergency as of 1 May 2022, travellers when entering Lithuania will no longer be subject to COVID-19 restrictions from the said date:
The passengers are not required to complete the passenger questionnaire neither to have a negative test for COVID-19, even they have not been vaccinated or recovered from COVID-19 disease, travellers from any country of the world are not subject to any requirements – Covid tests, as well as the questionnaires, are no longer needed; there will be no longer requirement to meet the exemption criteria or obtain a special permit to enter Lithuania.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Other Internal Border Restriction
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 21 February 2020, the National Public Health Center of Lithuania recommends that people who are returning to Lithuania from China to avoid contact with other people. The National Public Health Center advises remote work as a way of avoiding contact. If this is not possible individuals are able to claim 14 days of sick day leave. In cases where the individual is living with other people and alternative housing is not available, temporary housing can be requested.

type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)

description: Starting from 29 March 2021, the Lithuanian government announced the Principality of Andorra, Aruba, the Republic of Bulgaria, Kosovo, the French Republic, the Italian Republic, the Republic of Slovenia, the Republic of North Macedonia and the Oriental Republic of Uruguay have been added to the list of countries whence arrivals fall subject to tighter self-isolation requirements; the Republic of Slovenia has been removed from the list. There is a new requirement for crew members who plan to stay in Lithuania longer than 72 hours to bring in a negative COVID-19 test or get tested in Lithuania.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
On June 1, 2020, the Lithuanian Government announced travellers coming from Ireland, Malta and can enter Lithuania, but will be subject to a 14-day self-isolation period.
Easing the lockdown measures, the Lithuanian government has approved that travellers coming from 24 European countries will not be subject to 14 days of self-isolation upon arrival.
Restrictions have been lifted for citizens and lawful residents of the countries of the European Economic Area, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom, who arrive from one of these countries, provided the incidence of COVID-19 in the country where they lawfully reside was less than 15 cases/100 000 population in the last 14 days.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)

description:
The Ministry of Health of Lithuania announced that starting from July 6, 2020, the Democratic Republic of São Tomé and Príncipe have been removed from the quarantine requirement list, and nine other countries and territories without the status of a state have been added: Central African Republic , Montenegro, Costa Rica, Luxembourg, Palestine, the Sahara Arab Democratic Republic, Serbia, Turks and Caicos Islands and Ukraine. As of June 6th, 2020, 58 countries in total are therefore listed on the quarantine requirement list: Albania, Antigua and Barbuda, Argentine, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Bahrain, Belarus, Bangladesh, Bolivia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Brazil, Central African Republic, Chile,
Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Equatorial Guinea, Gabon, Guam, Guatemala, Honduras, Iraq, Iran, Israel, United States of America, United Arab Emirates, Montenegro, Qatar, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Colombia, Kosovo, Costa Rica, Kuwait, Luxembourg, Maldives, Mauritania, Mexico, Moldova, Oman, Pakistan, Palestine, Panama, Peru, South Africa, Portugal, Puerto Rico, Russian, Sahara, El Salvador, Saudi Arabia, Serbia, Singapore, Suriname, North Macedonia, Sweden, Turks & Caicos Islands, Ukraine, Cabo Verde. The list applies to Lithuanian citizens and residents, as well as foreign nationals who have permission to enter Lithuania.

description: Lithuania's Ministry of Health requires travellers from countries where the coronavirus incidence rate is over 25 cases per 100 000 citizens to quarantine for 14 days upon arrival in Lithuania. The Ministry of Health announced that starting July 6, 2020, the Democratic Republic of São Tomé and Príncipe have been removed from the quarantine requirement list, and nine other countries and territories without the status of a state have been added: Central African Republic , Montenegro, Costa Rica, Luxembourg, Palestine, the Sahara Arab Democratic Republic, Serbia, Turks and Caicos Islands and Ukraine. As of June 6th, 2020, 58 countries in total are therefore listed on the quarantine requirement list. The list applies to Lithuanian citizens and residents, as well as foreign nationals who have permission to enter Lithuania. UPDATE: From July 9th, self-isolation requirements for arrivals from another seven countries.

These travellers are required to isolate for 14 days upon arrival, but "the 14-day isolation will not apply in the case of: Citizens of Poland and Estonia and persons lawfully residing in these countries, who have returned or arrived for work, studies, agricultural activities or health care. People returning or transiting trough Poland from countries that are not affected by the coronavirus, only with essential stops, such as refuelling or hygiene, in Poland. description: Lithuania allowed citizens of European Economic Area countries and people legally residing in these countries to enter Lithuania on 28.10.2020. Travelers from red and grey zone countries will need to be tested for coronavirus (COVID-19) or quarantined for 10 days. If you have a certificate from a medical institution confirming that you are positive for coronavirus infection up to 3 months before entering Lithuania, isolation is not required. Vilnius will be in quarantine from 28 October 2020.

description: As of 2021 January 25, the Lithuanian government announced that people coming to Lithuania from almost every foreign country will need to get tested for Covid-19 no more than 48 hours before departure or within 24 hours after arrival, as well as self-isolate for two weeks. Only arrivals from Greece, Finland and parts of Norway are exempt. People coming from Norway's Oslo, Viken or Rogaland will still be required to have a coronavirus test and self-isolate. According to the Health Ministry, the 14-day self-isolation period can also be shortened after a person gets tested for Covid-19 on the tenth day of isolation at his or her own expense.

description: As of 2021 February 8, the Ministry of Health of Lithuania announced that all passengers coming to Lithuania need to present coronavirus test results and self-quarantine. Under the new rules, announced by the Health Ministry, all states have been included into the list of affected countries. All travellers coming to Lithuania now need to present a coronavirus test taken within the last 48 hours or register for one in Lithuania within a day after arriving as well as self-isolate for 14 days. Self-isolation is required even if the test result is negative. The self-isolation period can be shortened by taking another coronavirus test 10 days after coming to the country

description: As of 24 March 2020, the Lithuanian government announced stricter measures are imposed on all grocery stores in Lithuania. All visitors should disinfect their hands at the points of entry, shopping trolleys and shopping bags should be cleaned and disinfected after each use. Also, the government encourages installing partitions between staff and customers where possible. Distance between staff members and customers is least 2 meters, but the distance between customers should be at least 1 meter. Visitors should be encouraged to pay by cards. Ban on shopping in supermarkets for more than 2 individuals at a time comes into effect, family members have to go shopping by one.

description:
Starting from April 15, 2020, the Lithuanian government allowed operation of non-food stores on condition that they have a separate direct entrance from the outside and are able to regulate the flow of customers and other visitors.

Operation has been allowed for service businesses located in stationary service provision settings (supermarkets), such as cleaning services, key making, repair services, etc. They are not subject to the requirement to have a separate entrance from the outside. An additional restriction has been imposed on service providers: direct contact with the customer must not exceed 20 minutes.  Also, both non-food stores as well as household and repair service providers will have to guarantee at least 10 square meters of premises per customer or the ability to serve no more than one customer at a time.

description:
On April 22, 2020, Lithuanian government has announced the second phase of quarantine easing. The ban has been lifted as of Monday, 27 April, of hairdressers and nail parlours, outdoor cafes, libraries, museums and zoos, subject to certain requirements. There will also be a possibility of high-performance outdoor training of certain disciplines.

For cafes, restaurants and bars: they will be able to serve visitors only outdoors, and, as before, provide takeaway food. 

For hairdressers and nail parlours: they are required to ensure at least 10 sq. m. of space per customer and serve no more than one customer at a time, while following the mandatory hygiene requirements.

For certain cultural, leisure, entertainment and sports facilities: visits shall be restricted to groups of no more than two people, except where it is family members. 

For outdoor leisure activities in golf and outdoor tennis courts, outdoor shooting ranges, karting tracks and water board parks: they will be required to ensure 10 sq. m. of space per person, and a distance of at least 10 m between visitors. UPDATE: From April 27th, 2020, outdoor bars and cafes will be allowed to reopen as part of Lithuania's gradual exit from coronavirus lockdown. However, restrictions still apply.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Other Businesses

For certain cultural, leisure, entertainment and sports facilities: visits shall be restricted to groups of no more than two people, except where it is family members.

UPDATE: From April 27th, 2020, outdoor bars and cafes will be allowed to reopen as part of Lithuania's gradual exit from coronavirus lockdown. However, restrictions still apply.

description:
On April 28th, 2020, Lithuania’s health ministry has imposed strict physical distancing rules and safety measures. Shops must limit the number of customers at one time, masks will remain mandatory in all public spaces, and cafe and restaurant tables have to be placed at least two metres apart.

He also added that "Plazas, squares, streets – nearby cafes will be allowed to set up outdoor tables free of charge this season and thus conduct their activities during quarantine."

description:
On April 28th, 2020, Lithuania’s health ministry has imposed strict physical distancing rules and safety measures. Shops must limit the number of customers at one time, masks will remain mandatory in all public spaces, and cafe and restaurant tables have to be placed at least two metres apart.

He also added that "Plazas, squares, streets – nearby cafes will be allowed to set up outdoor tables free of charge this season and thus conduct their activities during quarantine."
 UPDATE: From the 21st of May, restaurants in the Lithuanian capital Vilnius are reopening in style with mannequins filling seats left empty because of social distancing guidelines.

The country this week began lifting lockdown restrictions on bars and restaurants, allowing them to use some indoor seating.

description:
As of May 30, 2020, Lithuania's government allowed spas to reopen. UPDATE: The nationwide quarantine, which was introduced in Lithuania in mid-March, will be lifted on June 17, the government decided on Wednesday. However, some restrictions will remain in place. After June 17, wearing facemasks in public will no longer be mandatory, but still recommended. At the moment, everyone must wear masks in shops, public transport, museums and other indoor public spaces.

Outdoor events will remain restricted to 700 people until the end of June and 1,000 people afterwards. Indoor events are not allowed to have more than 150, and 200 people after July 1.

Exceptions will apply in the case of takeaway food, or when food is delivered to the homes, premises of companies, establishments or organisations, or in the case of outdoor catering, or when gambling houses (casinos) and amusement arcades, bingo halls have no catering services.

description: As of November 18, 2020, the Lithuanian government has specified the restrictions on leisure, sports, and entertainment services by banning the provision of services of leisure, sports facilities, sports clubs, entertainment, recreation, swimming pools, saunas (except for public baths for personal hygiene), discos, dance halls, cinemas, and cinema clubs. The provision of these services shall be prohibited regardless of whether they are provided by natural or legal persons. It is also forbidden to visit or rent leisure facilities for private events, celebrations, or other gatherings. The exemption shall apply to high-performance sports training and individual (per visitor) physical activity sessions provided by a physical activity or sports specialist, instructor, or physical activity or sports specialist service provider. When organizing such sessions, it is necessary to ensure the conditions for the management of the flow of persons, the maintenance of a safe distance, as well as the necessary conditions for the safety of public health, hygiene, and the provision of the necessary personal protective equipment, as set by the State Commander of National Emergency Operations.

description:
As of December 2, 2020, in Lithuania, it is recommended to refrain from short-term sales promotion measures (sales, discount hours, tastings, etc.) in all shops, supermarkets, marketplaces and other public points of service. This does not apply to e-commerce. Also, the Government has agreed to ban the operation of temporary vendors in shops, supermarkets and points of service, where sales are not made in physically separated premises but in common areas and passageways of malls and supermarkets. Exceptions apply to selling foodstuffs,
pyrotechnic items and also to fixed vending stalls.

description: Starting from December 16, 2020, due to a nationwide lockdown in Lithuania, non-food shops will have to close or move trading online. Veterinary and food shops, pharmacies, optical and orthopedic shops will remain open. Food markets will also be allowed to stay open. Exceptions apply to Christmas tree vendors, who can continue to operate outdoors. Services that involve physical contact for more than 15 minutes are prohibited, including hairdressers and other beauty services. Exceptions apply to psychotherapy, emotional, and other health services, as well as professional legal and financial services that cannot be provided remotely. Also, hotels and housing services are allowed to stay open as long as only people from the same household share the accommodation. Hotels are restricted to accommodate foreign visitors or visitors from other cities.

description: Starting from December 16, 2020, due to a nationwide lockdown in Lithuania, non-food shops will have to close or move trading online. Veterinary and food shops, pharmacies, optical and orthopedic shops will remain open. Food markets will also be allowed to stay open. Exceptions apply to Christmas tree vendors, who can continue to operate outdoors. Services that involve physical contact for more than 15 minutes are prohibited, including hairdressers and other beauty services. Exceptions apply to psychotherapy, emotional, and other health services, as well as professional legal and financial services that cannot be provided remotely. Also, hotels and housing services are allowed to stay open as long as only people from the same household share the accommodation. Hotels are restricted to accommodate foreign visitors or visitors from other cities.

description: Starting from the 15th of February, 2021, the Lithuanian government allows non-food shops, kiosks and pavilions (except for those in the marketplace) with a sales area not exceeding 300 m2 to resume activities. Sales outlets will have to ensure there is a serving area of 20m2 or more, or serve only one customer at a time. Stores will be required to have a direct outside entrance and control customer flow. Selling flowers indoors, outdoors, hairdressers and beauty salons can resume their activities from the 15th. Individual activities outdoors supervised by coaches and instructors will be allowed on a 1-1 basis.

description: From the 15th of February, 2021, Lithuania allows non-food shops, kiosks and pavilions (except for those in the marketplace) with a sales area not exceeding 300 m2 to resume activities. Sales outlets will have to ensure there is a serving area of 20m2 or more, or serve only one customer at a time. Stores will be required to have a direct outside entrance and control customer flow.     Selling flowers indoors and outdoors can resume from the 15th.     Hairdressers and beauty salons will be able to resume activities from the 15th.     Individual activities outdoors supervised by coaches and instructors will be allowed on a 1-1 basis. UPDATE: From 15 March 2021 all shops with direct street access, as well as museums and galleries can reopen. They are required to ensure that a maximum number of visitors does not exceed one person per 20 m sq, and 2 meters distance must be maintained, with the exception of members of the same family.

Starting from May 18, 2020 the Lithuanian government announced that all indoor places, including restaurants, cafes, bars, nightclubs, casinos and entertainment venues, will be allowed to open between 08:00 and 22:00.

description: In Lithuania, starting from March 27, 2021 the provision of public transport is restricted for the movement of persons between municipalities,  except in cases where: to a municipality of place of residence, to a municipality other than the place of residence due to death of close relative;- for work when the place of work is in another municipality, to or from international passenger routes, airports, seaports, bus stations, to receive health care,  in urgent cases where it is necessary to provide assistance/care for a sick or vulnerable person, to/from municipalities adjacent to major cities, for other urgent/essential matters. Restrictions are in place until 6 April.

description: Starting from March 12, 2020, until March 27, 2020 the Lithuanian government prohibits outdoor events of more than 100 participants . Outdoor events with less than 100 participants can take place but only if the organizers ensure the possibility to take care of hand hygiene and guarantee that there will be no visitors to the event from countries declared as affected areas. Also, when organizing events, the audience should be taken into account - the majority of it should not consist of people in the risk group, i.e. y seniors with chronic diseases.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: All Recreational or commercial events allowed to occur with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Starting from May 18, 2020 the Lithuanian government announced that all indoor places, including restaurants, cafes, bars, nightclubs, casinos and entertainment venues, will be allowed to open between 08:00 and 22:00.

description: As of 24 March 2020, the Lithuanian government announced stricter measures are imposed on all grocery stores in Lithuania. All visitors should disinfect their hands at the points of entry, shopping trolleys and shopping bags should be cleaned and disinfected after each use. Also, the government encourages installing partitions between staff and customers where possible. Distance between staff members and customers is least 2 meters, but the distance between customers should be at least 1 meter. Visitors should be encouraged to pay by cards. Ban on shopping in supermarkets for more than 2 individuals at a time comes into effect, family members have to go shopping by one.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
On 27 March, 2020, Latvia's passenger carriers, transport organizers and passengers adopted security measures to reduce the number of carried passengers.

Passenger carriers have been ordered to limit the number of carried passengers. For example, buses are allowed to carry no more than 50% of passengers the bus has seats for.
Carriers also have to ensure the driver is distanced from passengers and perform regular disinfection of the interior of the vehicle.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Starting from April 15, 2020, the Lithuanian government allowed operation of non-food stores on condition that they have a separate direct entrance from the outside and are able to regulate the flow of customers and other visitors.

Operation has been allowed for service businesses located in stationary service provision settings (supermarkets), such as cleaning services, key making, repair services, etc. They are not subject to the requirement to have a separate entrance from the outside. An additional restriction has been imposed on service providers: direct contact with the customer must not exceed 20 minutes.  Also, both non-food stores as well as household and repair service providers will have to guarantee at least 10 square meters of premises per customer or the ability to serve no more than one customer at a time.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Commercial Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
"On April 15, 2020, Lithuanian government has approved of the first phase of easing the lockdown, allowing operation of non-food stores on condition that they have a separate direct entrance from the outside and are able to regulate the flow of customers and other visitors.

Operation has been allowed for service businesses located in stationary service provision settings (supermarkets), such as cleaning services, key making, repair services, etc. They are not subject to the requirement to have a separate entrance from the outside. An additional restriction has been imposed on service providers: direct contact with the customer must not exceed 20 minutes." UPDATE: Starting on Thursday, April 23, 2020, all retailers, including those in shopping centres, will be allowed to reopen, as well as other businesses outlined in the second stage of the quarantine exit plan published last week.

description:
On April 22, 2020, Lithuanian government has announced the second phase of quarantine easing. The ban has been lifted as of Monday, 27 April, of hairdressers and nail parlours, outdoor cafes, libraries, museums and zoos, subject to certain requirements. There will also be a possibility of high-performance outdoor training of certain disciplines.

For cafes, restaurants and bars: they will be able to serve visitors only outdoors, and, as before, provide takeaway food. 

For hairdressers and nail parlours: they are required to ensure at least 10 sq. m. of space per customer and serve no more than one customer at a time, while following the mandatory hygiene requirements.

For certain cultural, leisure, entertainment and sports facilities: visits shall be restricted to groups of no more than two people, except where it is family members. 

For outdoor leisure activities in golf and outdoor tennis courts, outdoor shooting ranges, karting tracks and water board parks: they will be required to ensure 10 sq. m. of space per person, and a distance of at least 10 m between visitors. UPDATE: From April 27th, 2020, outdoor bars and cafes will be allowed to reopen as part of Lithuania's gradual exit from coronavirus lockdown. However, restrictions still apply.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Other Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On April 28th, 2020, Lithuania’s health ministry has imposed strict physical distancing rules and safety measures. Shops must limit the number of customers at one time, masks will remain mandatory in all public spaces, and cafe and restaurant tables have to be placed at least two metres apart.

He also added that "Plazas, squares, streets – nearby cafes will be allowed to set up outdoor tables free of charge this season and thus conduct their activities during quarantine."

description: From October 9, 2020, people of Raseiniai District in Lithuania are required to wear mask in public. UPDATE: The qualitative nature of the policy has changed. The Lithuanian government has decided in the beginning of October to introduce a local lockdown in Raseiniai District, Western Lithuania, for two weeks, starting from October 9. The measures applied by the district's local authority until now, i.e. the requirement to wear facemasks, to work and study from home, etc., will now be complemented by a midnight curfew for public catering and entertainment venues and restrictions on the number of people in shops.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: As of November 11, 2020, Lithuania’s government declared measures due to lockdown. Protective face masks are mandatory in all public places (for all from the age of 6). Passengers travelling by public transport (city, long-distance and suburban) will be required to travel seated maintaining the distance of at least one meter between each other. No visits to residential social care and health care establishments. Long-term and short-term visits in penitentiary establishments and remand prisons will be restricted.

description: Starting from November 12, 2020, the Cabinet looked into the issue of mask-wearing for children that had provoked considerable public debate and decided that children over the age of six in pre-school, pre-primary and primary education will not be required to wear protective equipment covering nose and mouth during the educational process. This will not exempt other students and they will be required to continue wearing protective equipment covering nose and mouth.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Starting from December 16, 2020, due to a nationwide lockdown in Lithuania, non-food shops will have to close or move trading online. Veterinary and food shops, pharmacies, optical and orthopedic shops will remain open. Food markets will also be allowed to stay open. Exceptions apply to Christmas tree vendors, who can continue to operate outdoors. Services that involve physical contact for more than 15 minutes are prohibited, including hairdressers and other beauty services. Exceptions apply to psychotherapy, emotional, and other health services, as well as professional legal and financial services that cannot be provided remotely. Also, hotels and housing services are allowed to stay open as long as only people from the same household share the accommodation. Hotels are restricted to accommodate foreign visitors or visitors from other cities.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Supermarkets/grocery stores
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
As of May 5, 2021, there are some social distancing requirements in Lithuania. 

It is recommended to wear face masks on public transport during the morning and evening peak hours.

It is recommended to wear face masks in public indoor places that are poorly ventilated, crowded, and it is impossible to maintain a safe distance from other people, also on public transport during the morning and evening peak hours.

Visiting patients in hospitals is only possible while wearing protective equipment that covers the nose and mouth.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on visiting hospitals

description: As of May 17, 2021, there will be restrictions for travelling by regular public transport in Lithuania: in long-distance and suburban transport, passengers will be required to travel seated at a distance of at least one meter between each other, as opposed to city transport, where they will be allowed to travel both sitting and standing, provided that a distance of at least one meter is maintained between them.    It will be allowed to travel by vehicles other than regular public transport (city, long-distance and suburban) or vehicles to commute to/from work, or to go to/from points of COVID-19 (coronavirus infection) vaccination, or to go on tours for up to 10 vaccinated or recovered persons, in groups of up to 2 persons or one family and/or one household members. When providing passenger transportation through a ride-hailing and taxi passenger car services, the driver of the vehicle will not be counted.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of May 17, 2021, Lithuanian government allows vaccinated or recovered persons to visit their loved ones in health care establishments. description: May 10, 2021, The Lithuanian government announced that non-formal education for children will be provided remotely or suspended except foreign language proficiency assessment examinations (credits) attended by maximum 5 pupils, non-formal outdoor education activities for children attended by maximum 10 children and indoor non-formal education activities for children in the territories of some municipalities attended by maximum 5 children, while ensuring 20 m2 of service delivery space per child or only one child is present at a time until May 31, 2021. UPDATE: May 20, 2021, The Lithuanian government announced that starting from May 24, 2021, non-formal education carried out remotely or suspended, except: foreign language proficiency assessment examinations (credits) attended by maximum 10 pupils until May 31, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Starting from July 1, 2021 the Lithuanian government announced that all private sector employees can return to their workplace. Also, face masks will still be mandatory for those over 6 years of age in indoor public spaces (e.g. stores, public transport, events, etc.), except when exercising or providing a service that can only be provided for unmasked customer and when wearing a face mask is not possible due to health condition or when wearing it may adversely affect health condition (it is recommended to wear a face shield).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Starting from May 18, 2020 the Lithuanian government announced that all indoor places, including restaurants, cafes, bars, nightclubs, casinos and entertainment venues, will be allowed to open between 08:00 and 22:00.
The indoor establishments need to ensure a space of five square metres per person, instead of the previously required 10 square metres. Sports activities will be allowed to resume, but will have to ensure five square metres per person and 2-metre distances between individuals.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
